choices.text: Recommend that the patient begin psychotherapy
Start the patient on an antidepressant medication
Tell the patient that she should wait another 6 weeks, during which time her mood will improve

questions.text: A 42-year-old woman presents with a 4-month history of depression, 9kg weight gain, fatigue, and loss of interest in activities. She is diagnosed with hypothyroidism and started on thyroid hormone. After 6 weeks, her thyroid levels normalize, but depressive symptoms persist. What is the next best step in management?
questions.solution:
Explanation of Answer:

  • This patient is likely suffering from a mood disorder secondary to a general medical condition, characterized by a depressed mood and loss of interest in activities she usually enjoyed.
  • Many of these mood disorders, especially those caused by an endocrine disorder, persist even after the underlying medical condition has been treated.
  • The physician should begin the patient on antidepressant medication.

Management of Depression

  1. Psychotherapy:
    • Cognitive Therapy (CT):
      • A structured, time-limited therapy (≈25 sessions) aimed at identifying and correcting cognitive distortions-the negative triad (self, world, future) that maintains depression.
      • Includes didactic education, cognitive restructuring, behavioral techniques, and homework assignments.
    • Other Psychotherapies: Interpersonal therapy (IPT), behavior therapy, and psychodynamic therapy are effective, especially in mild-to-moderate cases .
  2. Pharmacologic treatment:
    • SSRIs (e.g., Fluoxetine, Sertraline, Escitalopram)
      • Mechanism: Inhibit serotonin reuptake
      • First-line: Well-tolerated, minimal toxicity
      • Side effects: GI upset, sexual dysfunction, insomnia
    • SNRIs (e.g., Venlafaxine, Duloxetine)
      • Mechanism: Inhibit serotonin & norepinephrine reuptake
      • Used in: Depression with pain, anxiety
      • Side effects: Hypertension (Venlafaxine), nausea
    • Atypical Antidepressants
      • Bupropion: ↑ DA & NE; no sexual side effects; avoid in seizures
      • Mirtazapine: Sedating, weight gain; good for insomnia
    • TCAs (e.g., Amitriptyline, Nortriptyline)
      • Mechanism: Block serotonin & norepinephrine reuptake
      • Side effects: Anticholinergic effects, sedation, cardiotoxicity
    • Combination of psychotherapy and pharmacotherapy is found to have good response by the patient.
    • Electroconvulsive therapy is used in severe cases and when resistant to other treatment modalities.

Explanation of Other Options:

Recommend that the patient begin psychotherapy(Option A): In moderate to severe depression, pharmacologic therapy is often required. Psychotherapy can be added later or used in combination, but not first-line treatment.

Increase the patient’s thyroid supplementation(Option B):Thyroid function is already normalized.Increasing the dose without indication could lead to iatrogenic hyperthyroidism, with risks such as arrhythmias and bone loss.

Tell the patient to wait another 6 weeks(Option D):There has already been an adequate trial of thyroid hormone (6 weeks) with normalization of TSH and T4. Since there is Persistence of depressive symptoms the patient needs to start on antidepressant .

questions.text: A 54-year-old man sees a physician complaining of a depressed mood and inability to sleep for the past 3 weeks. He reports previous similar episodes that responded well to a monoamine oxidase inhibitor. The physician diagnoses the patient with major depression and agrees to use an MAOI. Which of the following foods must be completely avoided by this patient while on this medication?
questions.solution:
Explanation for answer:

  • Monoamine oxidase inhibitors (MAOIs) block the breakdown of monoamines (like serotonin, dopamine, and norepinephrine) but also inhibit the breakdown of tyramine, a substance found in certain foods.
  • When tyramine builds up, it can lead to a hypertensive crisis—a dangerous spike in blood pressure. So in order to prevent this, they are advised strictly not to use foods containing high tyramine, like aged cheese, wine, etc.
  • To be completely avoided:
    • Aged cheese
    • Red wine
    • Cured meats
    • Soy sauce

questions.text: A 64-year-old man is admitted to the psychiatric unit following a suicide attempt. Following admission, he attempts to cut his wrists three times in the next 24 hours and refuses to eat or drink anything. The psychiatrist advised electroconvulsive therapy (ECT) after getting consent, taking into account the severity of symptoms and the need for faster action than antidepressants. Which of the following is the most common side effect immediately during the post-ECT period?
questions.solution:
Explanation for the answer:

  • The most common complaints after electroconvulsive therapy (ECT)include headaches, nausea, and muscle soreness.
  • Memory impairment(both retrograde and anterograde) does occur.
  • Likewise, cardiovascular changes do occur, but they are rare and happen mostly in the immediate postictal period or during the seizure itself.

questions.text:
A 27-year-old woman presents to the psychiatric outpatient department with a 15-day history of low mood, frequent crying spells, loss of interest in daily activities, early morning awakening, decreased appetite, and suicidal thoughts. These symptoms began after the recent death of her husband. She is currently 10 weeks pregnant and refuses hospital admission.
Which of the following antidepressant medications should be avoided in this patient?
questions.solution:
Explanation for answer:

  • Amongst all the antidepressants mentioned, Paroxetine is a Category D drug.
  • Selective Serotonin Reuptake Inhibitors(SSRIs) are prone to cause teratogenicity in the form of -
    • Heart defects like ASD, VSD in the first trimester
    • Pulmonary Hypertensionin the Third Trimester
  • A Category D drug has shown positive evidence of risk to the human fetus based on data from human studies or post-marketing experience. However, its potential benefits may outweigh the risks in certain clinical situations, such as life-threatening conditions or when safer alternatives are ineffective.
    • Lithium - associated with Ebstein's anomaly (a congenital heart defect).
    • Valproate - risk of neural tube defects.
    • Carbamazepine - also associated with neural tube defects.
    • Paroxetine (in early pregnancy) - linked to cardiac malformations.
  • Antidepressant medications during pregnancy:
    • SSRIs are commonly prescribed due to their favorable safety profile, with fluoxetine and sertraline having the most safety data among them.
    • Paroxetine, however, is associated with cardiac defects when used in the first trimester and should be avoided unless no alternatives exist.
    • Tricyclic antidepressants are also viable options, though their side effects such as constipation and orthostatic hypotension may worsen during pregnancy.

questions.text: A 32-year-old woman with cyclothymia presents to the obstetrician in the first trimester for a routine prenatal visit. She has continued her prescription of valproate during pregnancy. Which of the following is the most likely abnormality that might be detected on an ultrasound examination due to the effects of the mood stabilizer?
questions.solution:
Explanation for answer:

  • Valproate (valproic acid) is a well-known mood stabilizer used in bipolar disorder and cyclothymia.
  • Maternal use of valproate, especially in the first trimester, is associated with an increased risk of foetal neural tube defects such as spina bifida.
  • Increasing folic acid supplements(1-4 mg daily) can help reduce the risk of birth defects.
  • For women of reproductive age, ensure appropriate contraception if prescribing a medication associated with teratogenicity.
  • Lamotrigine is considered the mood stabilizer of choice during pregnancy due to its low risk of major congenital malformations.

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman was diagnosed with bipolar disorder, manic type, when she was hospitalized after becoming psychotic, hypersexual, severely agitated, and unable to sleep. She has started on medication in the acute phase of her illness. Now that her symptoms have stabilized, which of the following medications, known for its role in acute mania management, is also recommended to be continued as maintenance therapy?
questions.solution:
Explanation for answer:

  • Lithium,valproic acid, olanzapine, lamotrigine, quetiapine are the agents most often used in the long-term maintenance treatment of bipolar disorder.
  • Psychoeducation also need to be incorporated into the treatment during the maintenance therapy.It is providing information to the patient and their family about the nature of the disease, its treatment and coping strategies with the disease
  • Antipsychotics and benzodiazepines, while very helpful in the acute treatment of bipolar mania, should be discontinued as soon as the patient is in a stable state and not used in long-term maintenance unless necessary, given the risk of movement disorders and dependence, respectively.

choices.text: Mood disorder secondary to a general medical condition

questions.text: A 26-year-old man comes to the physician with the chief complaint of a depressed mood for the past 5 weeks. He has been feeling down, with decreased concentration, energy, and interest in his usual hobbies. Six weeks before this office visit, he had been to the emergency room for an acute asthma attack and was started on prednisone. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation for answer:

  • According to DSM-5 criteria, patients developing a mood disorder after using a substance(either illicit or prescribed)are diagnosed with a substance-induced mood disorder.
  • The diagnosis of major depression cannot be made in the presence of either substance use or a general medical condition that might be the cause of the mood disorder.
  • Prednisone is a common culprit in causing mood disordersranging from depression to mania to psychosis.

Explanation of other options:

Mood disorder secondary to a general medical condition(Option A):This diagnosis is used when a medical illness itself (e.g., hypothyroidism, stroke) causes the mood symptoms.In the clinical scenario discussed, the mood symptoms are linked to medication (prednisone), not the underlying asthma.

Major depression((Option C):While the symptoms meet the criteria for a major depressive episode, this diagnosis is made only if the depression is not attributable to substances or medical conditions.Because the depressive episode followed prednisone use, this is more accurately classified as substance-induced.

Adjustment disorder(Option D):Adjustment disorder involves emotional or behavioral symptoms in response to an identifiable stressful life event, occurring within 3 months of the stressor. The case discussed can be classified more accurately as substance induced than Adjustment Disorder .

choices.text: Mood disorder secondary to a general medical condition

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman visits her physician with the chief complaint of a depressed mood. She also notes that she is sleeping more than usual for up to 14 hours per night, but does not feel rested, and that she feels tired all the time. She has gained 6kg in the last month, something that she is very unhappy about, but she says that she seems to have such a craving for sweets that the weight gain seemed inevitable. She also reports experiencing a similar episode around the same time last year, which resolved on its own after a few months.Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation for answer:

  • In the given clinical scenario the patient presents with features of hypersomnia, increased appetite, carbohydrate craving ,along with a seasonal pattern observed. This is suggestive of most probably seasonal affective disorder(SAD).
  • Seasonal Affective Disorder (SAD) is a subtype of major depressive disorder that follows a seasonal pattern.The seasonal pattern specifier criteria(DSM 5)include:
    • Regular temporal relationship between the onset of major depressive episodes and a particular time of the year (unrelated to obvious season-related psychosocial stressors).
    • Full remissions (or a change to mania or hypomania) also occur at a characteristic time of the year.
    • Two major depressive episodes meeting criteria A and B have occurred in the last 2 years, and no nonseasonal episodes have occurred in the same period.
    • Seasonal major depressive episodes substantially outnumber the nonseasonal episodes over the individual’s lifetime.
  • Patients usually exhibit typical signs and symptoms seasonally, most often during thewinter, with symptoms remitting in the spring.
  • Hypersomnia and hyperphagia (atypical signs of depression) are classically seen with this disorder
  • Light therapy and serotonergic agents(typically SSRIs) are the treatments of choice for this disorder.

Explanation of other options:

Mood disorder secondary to a general medical condition(Option A):This diagnosis is made when depression is directly caused by a medical illness (e.g., hypothyroidism, stroke, multiple sclerosis).Here there is no evidence of a medical condition causing the symptoms.

Substance-induced mood disorder(Option B):It refers to mood disturbances caused by drugs, alcohol, or medications (e.g., steroids, stimulants).There is no history of recent substance use or medication that could account for her symptoms.

Cyclothymia(Option C):A chronic mood disorder involving frequent mood swings between hypomanic and depressive symptoms, lasting at least 2 years, but not meeting full criteria for mania or major depression.This patient has clear unipolar, seasonal depressive episodes, with no history of hypomanic symptoms, ruling out cyclothymia.

questions.text: A 27-year-old woman has been in a depressed mood for the past 2 weeks. She has little energy and has trouble concentrating. She states that 6 weeks ago, she had been feeling very good, with lots of energy and no need for sleep. She says that this pattern has been occurring for at least the past 3 years, though the episodes have never been so severe that she couldn't work. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation for answer:

  • Cyclothymic disorder is characterized by recurrent periods of mild depression alternating with periods of hypomania.
  • This pattern must be present for at least 2 years(1 year for children and adolescents) before the diagnosis can be made.
  • During these 2 years, the symptom-free intervals should not be longer than 2 months.
  • Cyclothymic disorder usually starts during adolescence or early adulthoodand tends to have a chronic course.
  • The marked shifts in mood of cyclothymic disorder can be confused with the affective instability of borderline personality disorder or may suggest a substance abuse problem.

Explanation of other options:

Borderline Personality Disorder(Option A): This may include mood instability, but primarily defined by interpersonal instability, identity disturbance, chronic feelings of emptiness, and impulsivity, not by cyclical mood episodes lasting weeks.The patient's symptoms follow a cyclical, longitudinal pattern, not the rapid mood shifts seen in borderline personality disorder.

Seasonal Affective Disorder(Option B):Refers to depressive episodes with a seasonal pattern, typically in fall/winter and resolving in spring.This patient’s symptoms are not season-dependent, and include elevated mood phases, which are not part of SAD.

Major Depression, Recurrent(Option D):It requires at least two episodes of major depressive disorder, separated by periods of remission.While the patient has depressive symptoms, they do not meet full criteria for a major depressive episode, and she also experiences hypomanic symptoms, which are not part of unipolar depression.

questions.text: A 19-year-old woman comes to the psychiatrist for a history of anger and irritability, which occurs monthly. During this time, the patient also reports feeling anxious and 'about to explode', which alternates rapidly with crying spells and angry outbursts. She also noticed during this time, she impaired concentration and hypersomnia than she usually needs to. During the days these symptoms last, the patient skips most of her classes because she cannot function. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation for answer:

  • Premenstrual dysphoric disorder (PMDD)is an illness that is triggered by the changing levels of hormones that occur during a menstrual cycle.
  • It occurs approximately 1 week before the onset of menses.
  • Characterized by:
    • Headaches
    • Anxiety
    • Depression
    • Irritability
    • Emotional lability
  • Other symptoms:
    • Oedema
    • Weight gain
    • Breast pain
  • Approximately 5% of womensuffer from this disorder.
  • Some patients respond to short courses of SSRIs, in addition to symptomatic treatment with analgesics and diuretics.

Explanation of other options:

Adjustment disorder with depressed mood(Option A):Triggered by a specific identifiable stressor, not monthly hormonal cycles and symptoms usually not recur in a predictable menstrual pattern.

Major depression(Option B): To diagnose as major depression the patient requires persistent symptoms for ≥2 weeks, but the monthly periodicity or cyclical nature tied to menstruation is suggestive of PMDD.

Dysthymic disorder (Persistent Depressive Disorder)(Option D): It involves chronic low mood for ≥2 years, without regular symptom-free intervals.This patient exhibits distinct episodes of symptoms tied to her cycle, not continuous low mood.

questions.text:
A 19-year-old man is brought to the emergency department by police after being found wandering naked in his neighborhood. He reports receiving "amazing messages from the cosmosphere" and believes he is destined to do something "catastrophically wonderful" for the world. He displays alternating euphoria and irritability, and mentions buying a new car on his credit card. He denies any medical illness, and a urine drug screen is negative.
What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation for answer:

  • The man is presenting with labile mood, inappropriate behavior, grandiose thoughts, and excessive spending, all hallmarks of bipolar disorder with manic episode.
  • Clinical Features of Bipolar I in manic episode:
    • Elevated or irritable mood
    • Inflated self-esteem (grandiosity)
    • Decreased need for sleep
    • Increased talkativeness (pressured speech)
    • Flight of ideas
    • Distractibility
    • Increase in goal-directed activity or psychomotor agitation
    • Excessive involvement in risky activities (spending sprees, sexual indiscretions)
  • Management of Bipolar Disorder
  • Acute Mania:
  • First-line: Mood stabilizers such as:
    • Lithium
    • Valproate
    • Atypical antipsychotics (e.g., Olanzapine, Risperidone, Aripiprazole
    • Benzodiazepines (short-term) may help with agitation/sleep
  • Maintenance Treatment:
    • Continue mood stabilizers (Lithium, Valproate, Lamotrigine)
    • Lamotrigine is especially helpful in bipolar depression
    • Atypical antipsychotics (e.g., Quetiapine, Aripiprazole) are often used for maintenance
  • Psychotherapy:
    • Psychoeducation
    • Cognitive behavioral therapy (CBT)
    • Family-focused therapy to reduce relapses

Explanation of other options:

Schizoaffective Disorder(Option A):Requires mood symptoms and psychotic symptoms, but psychosis must occur for at least 2 weeks in the absence of mood symptoms.In this case, psychotic features are clearly occurring in the context of elevated mood, not independently → rules out schizoaffective disorder.

Schizophrenia(Option B):Involves persistent psychotic symptoms (e.g., delusions, hallucinations, disorganized speech) for ≥6 months, with functional decline.The patient's symptoms are episodic, and his mood disturbance is prominent (euphoria, irritability) → more consistent with bipolar I disorder.

Cyclothymic Disorder(Option D):Involves chronic fluctuating mood symptoms (hypomania + mild depression) for ≥2 years, without meeting full criteria for mania or major depression.This patient meets full criteria for a manic episode (psychosis, grandiosity, risky behavior), so cyclothymia does not apply.

questions.text: A 30-year-old man comes to the psychiatrist for evaluation of a depressed mood. He states that at least since his mid-20s, he has felt depressed. He notes poor self-esteem and low energy and feels hopeless about his situation, though he denies suicidal ideation. He states he does not use drugs or alcohol and has no medical problems. His last physical examination by his physician 1 month ago was entirely normal. Which of the following treatment options should be tried first?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • In the clinical scenario discussed, the patient has had a persistent mild-to-moderate depressed mood since his mid-20s, accompanied by low energy, poor self-esteem, and hopelessness, but no suicidal ideation or psychosis These findings align best with Dysthymia(Persistent Depressive Disorder) -a chronic, subthreshold depression lasting for years.
  • Dysthymia, now formally known as Persistent Depressive Disorder (PDD) in DSM-5, is a chronic, low-grade depression characterized by depressed mood most of the day, more days than not, lasting at least 2 years in adults. Episodes never meet full criteria for a major depressive episode, but the symptoms can significantly impair functioning and quality of life
  • Venlafaxine and bupropion are generally believed to be the treatments of choice for dysthymic disorder, though there is a subgroup of patients who will respond to the MAOIs as well. TCAs, SSRIs, and MAOIs seem to be reasonable choices for those suffering from dysthymia, although SSRIs are probably the better choice because of their acceptability.

choices.text: Initiate antipsychotic therapy to stabilize psychosis
Assist in locating long-term rehabilitation housing

questions.text: A 40-year-old homeless man with schizophrenia is brought to the emergency department by a social worker. He has not eaten in two days, appears severely malnourished, and is disoriented. According to Maslow's hierarchy of needs, which of the following should be the immediate focus of management?
questions.solution:
Explanation for answer:

  • In the given clinical scenario, according to Maslow's Hierarchy of Needs, physiological needs (like food, water, warmth, and rest) are the most basic and urgent.
  • In this case, malnutrition and dehydration should be addressed before initiating psychiatric treatment or long-term plans.
  • Only once basic needs are met can higher-order needs (safety, love, esteem) be effectively targeted

questions.text: A 25-year-old woman from a rural community is brought to the emergency department after attempting self-immolation following her husband's death in a conflict. Her family states this act was part of an age-old community practice expected of widows. This behavior reflects which of the following types of suicide according to Durkheim's classification?
questions.solution:
Explanation for answer:

  • This clinical case describes a 25-year-old widow who attempted self-immolation after her husband’s death, as part of an age-old cultural tradition expected by her community. This type of suicide is best understood as altruistic suicide, according to Émile Durkheim’s sociological classification of suicide.
  • 'Johar' and 'Sati' are the primitive superstitious practices or culture-bound syndromes in India where women would sacrifice their lives due to an excessive level of integration, like for a religion/cult, hence an example of Altruistic suicide.
  • He divided suicides into four social categories:
    1. Egoistic
    2. Altruistic
    3. Anomic
    4. Fatalistic
  • Altruistic suicide applies to those susceptible to suicide stemming from their excessive integration into a group, with suicide being the outgrowth of the integration.

Explanation of other options:

Egoistic suicide (Option A) occurs when an individual feels profoundly disconnected from their social groups, excessively individuated and lacking social integration.

Anomic suicide (Option B) happens in times of sudden social or economic upheaval, when individuals lack the regulatory norms to guide their aspirations and behavior.

Fatalistic suicide (Option D) arises under conditions of excessive regulation, where individuals experience oppressive, constricting circumstances that eliminate their sense of autonomy.

questions.text: Which of the following antipsychotic drugs does not act as a partial agonist at dopamine receptors?
questions.solution:
Explanation for answer:

  • Olanzapine blocks D2 receptors and doesn't have intrinsic agonist properties.
  • The antipsychotic drugs that have dopamine partial agonist action are
    1. Aripiprazole
    2. Brexpiprazole
    3. Cariprazine
  • Amisulpride doesn't have intrinsic agonistic effects but acts as an antagonist on presynaptic D2 autoreceptor and increases levels of dopamine at lower doses.

questions.text: Which drug should be prescribed with caution in conjunction with fluvoxamine?
questions.solution:
Explanation of Answer:

  • Fluvoxamine is a selective serotonin reuptake inhibitor (SSRI) commonly used to treat OCD and depression. It has significant effects on cytochrome P450 enzymes.
  • Naproxen is a nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drug (NSAID).
  • SSRIs like fluvoxamine increase the risk of gastrointestinal (GI) bleeding due to platelet dysfunction.
  • When combined with NSAIDs, which independently increase GI bleeding risk, the effect becomes additive or synergistic. In addition, it should be used with gastroprotective measures like proton pump inhibitors when given together with lithium(or non-steroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs), St John's wort, tryptophan, or warfarin.

Explanation of other options:

Amitriptyline (Option A): Metabolized by CYP2D6. Fluvoxamine inhibits other CYPs more strongly. Monitor levels, but less critical than GI bleeding risk.

Amlodipine (Option B): Metabolized by CYP3A4. No major interaction with fluvoxamine. Generally safe.

Chlorpromazine(Option C) :Mild CYP2D6 metabolism interaction. Caution needed, but not as significant as NSAID-SSRI bleeding risk.

questions.text: A 30-year-old man was stable on regular antipsychotic medication until 4 days ago, when he was admitted with a severe acute psychotic episode. Since then, he has developed hyperpyrexia, muscular rigidity, profuse sweating, and disorientation. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation for answer:

  • The patient has developed signs of the neuroleptic malignant syndrome.
  • This is characterised by hyperthermia, rigidity, confusion, and autonomic lability.
  • It has a reported High mortality rateof 20% and it can result in residual neurological deficits in survivors.
  • Treatment:
    • The neuroleptic malignant syndrome usually resolves on discontinuation of the implicated antipsychotic and medical measures such as rehydration, correction of electrolytes and benzodiazepines if necessary. 
    • Dantroleneis another medication that can be used if necessary.

Explanation of other options:

Akathisia(Option A):A subjective feeling of restlessness and inability to sit still.Symptoms include Pacing, leg tapping, anxiety but NOT fever or rigidity.

Dystonic Reaction(Option B):It is an Acute extrapyramidal side effect with time of onset varying from Hours to days after antipsychotic initiation.Symptoms include Sustained involuntary muscle contractions (e.g., torticollis, oculogyric crisis),but No fever, no autonomic dysfunction, no altered mental status. It is treated with Anticholinergics like benztropine or diphenhydramine.

Serotonin Syndrome(Option D):Excess serotonin activity — classically from SSRIs, MAOIs, or serotonergic drug combinations (e.g., SSRI + linezolid).Symptoms include Hyperreflexia, clonus, tremor,Agitation, diarrhea etc.

questions.text: A 34-year-old patient with major depressive disorder and significant insomnia is started on mirtazapine. Which of the following best describes its primary mechanism of action?
questions.solution:
Explanation for answer:

  • Mirtazapine is classified as a noradrenergic and selective serotonergic antidepressant. (Atypical antidepressants)
  • α2-receptors are presynaptic autoreceptors that normally inhibit the release of norepinephrine (NE) and serotonin (5-HT).
  • By blocking α2-receptors, mirtazapine:
    • ↑ Norepinephrine release
    • ↑ Serotonin release (especially via 5-HT1A receptors)
  • Additionally, mirtazapine blocks 5-HT2A, 5-HT2C, and 5-HT3 receptors, leading to fewer side effects like anxiety, sexual dysfunction, and nausea (commonly associated with SSRIs).
  • It also blocks H1 histamine receptors → causing sedation and weight gain, often used beneficially in depressed patients with insomnia or anorexia.

questions.text: A 29-year-old man with schizophrenia is started on medication to target his positive symptoms, such as hallucinations and delusions. Which of the following drugs primarily acts as a dopamine D2 antagonist to achieve this effect?
questions.solution:
Explanation for answer:

Risperidone:

  • Class: Atypical antipsychotic
  • Mechanism of Action:
    • Potent antagonist at dopamine D2 receptors
    • Also antagonizes 5-HT2A (serotonin) receptors
    • Used for:
      • Schizophrenia (positive & negative symptoms)
      • Bipolar disorder
      • Irritability in autism spectrum disorder

questions.text: A 24-year-old man has recently completed heroin detoxification. He refuses opioid maintenance therapy but requests medication to help maintain abstinence. Which of the following drugs is the most appropriate choice for relapse prevention in this patient?
questions.solution:
Explanation for answer:

  • The National Institute for Health and Care Excellence(NICE) recommends the use of naltrexone for those who prefer an abstinence programme.
  • Patients need to be fully informed of the potential adverse effects and benefits of treatment and should be highly motivated to remain on treatment.
  • Naltrexone treatment has been found by NICE to be a cost-effective treatment strategyin aiding abstinence from opioid misuse.
  • Opioid maintenance therapy, which the patient refused, is usually done with methadone and buprenorphine.

Explanation of other options:

Codeine (Option A) is a weak opioid agonist used primarily as a cough suppressant and mild analgesic, not used for opioid relapse prevention.

Disulfiram (Option B) is an aversive agent for alcohol dependence that inhibits aldehyde dehydrogenase, causing unpleasant reactions when alcohol is consumed.

Naloxone (Option C) is a short-acting opioid antagonist used for emergency reversal of opioid overdose, but not effective for long-term relapse prevention.

questions.text: A 40-year-old man with alcohol dependence is started on medication to help maintain abstinence by reducing cravings. Which of the following best describes the mechanism of action of this medication?
questions.solution:
Explanation for answer:

  • In the clinical scenario the 40-year-old man with alcohol dependence is started on a medication that helps maintain abstinence by reducing cravings which most likely prescribed in this context is acamprosate which is a N-Methyl-d-aspartate receptor antagonist .
  • In chronic alcohol use, glutamate (excitatory) activity is upregulated and GABA (inhibitory) activity is downregulated.
  • Upon alcohol withdrawal, this imbalance leads to hyperexcitability and craving.
  • Acamprosate restores this balance by:
    • Inhibiting NMDA receptors (↓ excitatory glutamate)
    • Enhancing GABAergic tone (↑ inhibitory effect)

questions.text: A 30-year-old man with treatment-resistant schizophrenia is started on clozapine. Two weeks later, he reports bothersome hypersalivation. Which of the following mechanisms most likely explains this side effect?
questions.solution:
Explanation for answer:

  • Clozapine has marked anticholinergic activity. It acts as amuscarinic receptor blocker except for M4-receptor agonism. This is likely to cause hypersalivation.
  • In addition, α2-receptor antagonism could increase salivation.

Explanation of other options:

5-HT2 antagonism(Option A):This contributes to antipsychotic effects and less extrapyramidal symptoms, but not to sialorrhea.

α2-Receptor antagonism(Option B):Causes orthostatic hypotension due to vasodilation.

D2-Receptor antagonism(Option D):D2 antagonism contributes to some antipsychotic effects

questions.text: A 35-year-old man with bipolar disorder is started on lithium therapy. Which of the following is an acute side effect associated with this medication?
questions.solution:
Explanation for answer:

  • Fine tremor is an acute side effect of lithium therapy.

questions.text: A 21-year-old woman with an acute first psychotic episode was started on olanzapine 15 mg at night. After 10 days, she developed rigidity, pyrexia, and autonomic instability. What is the most likely cause?
questions.solution:
Explanation for answer:

  • In the given clinical scenario, the patient developed symptoms of hyperpyrexia, muscular rigidity, and autonomic instability 10 days after initiating treatment with the antipsychotic drug olanzapine.
  • These features are characteristic of Neuroleptic Malignant Syndrome (NMS), a rare but potentially life-threatening adverse effect associated with dopamine D2 receptor antagonism seen in antipsychotic therapy.
  • Neuroleptic malignant syndrome:
    • According to the DSM-IV, NMS is characterised by muscle rigidityand an elevated temperature and is associated with the administration of an antipsychotic medication.
    • Two or more symptoms of autonomic instabilityneed to be present, and blood investigations should be instigated.
    • There is an absence of infection, general medical condition, or substance use that may result in a similar condition.
    • It is estimated to occur in 0.2-1% of patients treated with dopamine-blocking agents.
    • It is also known to occur in other neurological disorders (e.g., Wilson's disease, Parkinson's disease treated with dopamine-blocking agents).
    • It may also occur in patients treated with dopamine antagonists given for nausea (e.g., metoclopramide, prochlorperazine).

Explanation of other options:

Acute Dystonia (Option A): This is usually not associated with pyrexia and autonomic instability.

Encephalitis (Option B): This may present with a viral prodrome, meningeal signs, other neurological signs, seizures and imaging and cerebrospinal fluid abnormalities.

Malignant catatonia (Option C): Idiopathic malignant catatonia is due to advanced stages of psychosis and may be difficult to differentiate from NMS, which is also thought to be an iatrogenic malignant catatonia.

questions.text: A 45-year-old man with a family history of diabetes mellitus presented with psychotic symptoms. Which of the following antipsychotics does not interfere with blood sugar?
questions.solution:
Explanation for answer:

  • Amisulpride does not interfere with blood sugar levels.
  • It is a selective dopamine D2 and D3 receptor antagonist, with preferential limbic selectivity.
  • At low doses, it preferentially blocks presynaptic D2/D3 autoreceptors, enhancing dopamine transmission.
  • At higher doses, it blocks postsynaptic D2/D3 receptors, exerting antipsychotic effects.
  • Uses:
    • Primarily used for schizophrenia and acute psychotic episodes.
  • Side Effects:
    • Hyperprolactinemia, leading to galactorrhea, amenorrhea, and gynecomastia.
    • Extrapyramidal symptoms (EPS), particularly at higher doses
    • QT prolongation (dose-dependent).

Explanation of other options:

Clozapine(Option B): It is a D2 receptor antagonist + 5HT2A antagonist. It is used in Treatment-resistant schizophrenia, suicidality in schizophrenia.Side Effects include Very high risk of metabolic syndrome: causes significant weight gain, hyperglycemia, dyslipidemia,Agranulocytosis (requires regular CBC monitoring),Seizures (dose-dependent),Sialorrhea, myocarditis, orthostatic hypotension.

Olanzapine(Option C):It is a Potent antagonist at D2 and 5HT2A receptors. It is used in Schizophrenia, bipolar disorder (acute mania and maintenance).Side Effects include High risk for metabolic side effects, including weight gain, insulin resistance, and hyperglycemia,Sedation, anticholinergic effects, orthostatic hypotension.

Quetiapine(Option D): It is an Antagonist at D2 and 5HT2A receptors; also acts on H1 and α1-adrenergic receptors. It is used in Schizophrenia, bipolar disorder, depression adjunct.Side Effects include Moderate risk for metabolic disturbances (weight gain, increased blood glucose).Sedation, orthostatic hypotension, anticholinergic effects.

Serum lithium levels increase in the third trimester of pregnancy.

questions.text: You get a call from the duty obstetrician about a 32-year-old woman who was 15 weeks pregnant and her bipolar affective disorder was stabilized on lithium. Which of the following statements about the use of lithium in pregnancy is correct?
questions.solution:
Explanation for answer:

  • Immediately after delivery, the serum concentration starts to rise, so lithium levels should be closely monitored
  • Lithiumis excreted in breast milk, so it should be explained clearly to the mother about the effect of lithium on newborn babies.(Option A)
  • Lithium can affect the baby during the second and third trimesters tion B)It can have toxic effects if serum lithium levels are very high and can also cause cardiac dysfunction, diabetes insipidus, and hypothyroidism in the fetus.
  • Lithium levels fall during the third trimester of pregnancy.
  • However,.
  • Lithium use is usually associated with Ebstein's anomalyof the tricuspid valve.

questions.text: An 18-year-old male, recently started on a medication, presents to the emergency department with slow, long-sustained, contorting, involuntary movements and postures involving proximal limb and axial muscles. Which of the following drugs is most likely responsible for these adverse effects?
questions.solution:
Explanation for answer:

  • The patient is exhibiting features of an acute dystonic reaction, a common extrapyramidal side effect of antipsychotic medications like Risperidone. This is more frequent in young males shortly after initiating treatment.

Risperidone:

  • Atypical antipsychotic
  • Mechanism: Potent D2 receptor antagonist and 5-HT2A antagonist
  • Can cause EPS, especially acute dystonia, akathisia, and parkinsonism, particularly at higher doses or in young males.

Explanation of other options:

Propranolol (Option A) is a beta-blocker used for anxiety and akathisia. Does not cause dystonia

Diazepam (Option B) is a benzodiazepine with muscle-relaxant and anxiolytic effects.It may be used to treat dystonia.

Sertraline (Option D) , an SSRI antidepressant, may cause mild movement disorders like tremor but is rarely associated with acute dystonia, which is more common with antipsychotics like risperidone.

questions.text: A 35-year-old woman with a history of major depressive disorder, currently on treatment, presents with complaints of reduced sexual desire and satisfaction. She reports significant distress, stating it is negatively impacting her marital relationship. Which of the following antidepressants would be the most appropriate alternative, known to have minimal sexual side effects?
questions.solution:
Explanation of Answer:

  • Mirtazapine, an atypical antidepressant that acts as an α2-adrenergic antagonist and 5-HT2/5-HT3 receptor antagonist, has a low risk of sexual side effects.It has minimal activation of serotonergic pathways (no serotonin reuptake inhibition), which is linked to a lower incidence of sexual side effects .

Explanation of other options:

Fluoxetine(Option A):A commonly used SSRI with high rates of sexual dysfunction, including decreased libido and delayed orgasm  .

Phenelzine(Option B):As an MAO Inhibitor, it carries a moderate-to-high risk of sexual dysfunction and is typically reserved for treatment-resistant cases  .

Venlafaxine (Option D):An SNRI that induces sexual side effects in a similar proportion of patients as SSRIs (~50%).

questions.text: A 29-year-old male with schizophrenia is being considered for a change in medication due to excessive daytime sedation on his current antipsychotic. Which of the following antipsychotic medications is least likely to cause sedation?
questions.solution:
Explanation for answer:

  • Sedation is a common side effect of many antipsychotics, especially low-potency first-generation agents and some second-generation drugs with strong antihistamine (H1-blocking) properties.
  • Aripiprazole is a second-generation (atypical) antipsychotic that acts as a partial agonist at dopamine D2 and serotonin 5-HT1A receptors and an antagonist at 5-HT2A receptors.It has minimal antihistaminic or anticholinergic activity, resulting in low sedation risk.
  • Main Indications are Schizophrenia, Bipolar I, adjunct in depression, autism-related irritability
  • Common Side Effects include Akathisia, insomnia, anxiety, GI symptoms.

Explanation of other options:

Chlorpromazine(option B):A low-potency first-generation antipsychotic.Strong histamine H1 receptor blocker → very sedating.

Clozapine(Option C):It is a second-generation antipsychotic used for treatment-resistant schizophrenia.Highly sedating due to H1 and muscarinic receptor blockade.Also associated with weight gain, metabolic syndrome, hypersalivation, and serious risks like agranulocytosis.

Promazine(option D): It is a low-potency first-generation antipsychotic, similar to chlorpromazine and has significant sedative properties due to strong antihistaminic and anticholinergic effects.

questions.text: A 30-year-old man with treatment-resistant schizophrenia is on high-dose clozapine medication. To reduce his risk of seizures, an anticonvulsant medication was introduced. He subsequently developed agranulocytosis requiring the intervention of a haematologist. Which of these anticonvulsant medications most likely would have contributed to his agranulocytosis in combination with clozapine?
questions.solution:
Explanation for answer:

  • The combination of carbamazepine and clozapinemay increase the risk of agranulocytosis due to the additive effect of bone marrow suppression and should be avoided in combination.
  • Carbamazepine, an anticonvulsant and mood stabilizer, also has hematological side effects, notably:
    • Agranulocytosis
    • Aplastic anemia
    • Leukopenia
  • Sodium valproateis recommended for prophylactic use in patients on clozapine in high doses or with plasma levels >500 μg/L.

Explanation of other options:

Sodium valproate (Option A) can cause thrombocytopenia, but agranulocytosis is rare

Lamotrigine (Option B) is associated with rash (Stevens-Johnson Syndrome), not agranulocytosis

Levetiracetam (Option D) is generally safe and has minimal hematological toxicity

questions.text: A 20-year-old ballet dancer presents to you with symptoms suggestive of depression and agrees to start antidepressant treatment. Which of the following antidepressants is most likely to cause weight loss in this woman?
questions.solution:
Explanation for answer:

  • Fluoxetine is an SSRI that is associated with appetite suppression and weight loss in the early phase of treatment. For a young weight-conscious patient like a ballet dancer, Fluoxetine is a suitable SSRI. While fluoxetine is associated with weight loss, paroxetine and fluvoxamine are known to cause weight gain.
  • Antidepressants vary in their potential to cause weight gain. Those associated with high weight gain include tricyclic antidepressants (such as amitriptyline, doxepin, and clomipramine), mirtazapine, mianserin, and paroxetine.
  • Moderate weight gain may occur with SSRIs other than paroxetine, particularly with long-term use.
  • Antidepressants associated with low or minimal weight gain include trazodone, vortioxetine, agomelatine, bupropion, duloxetine, and venlafaxine. This information is useful when selecting treatment for patients concerned about weight changes.

questions.text: A 45-year-old man in the medical ward on linezolid antibiotic for an infection developed confusion, muscle rigidity, and hyperthermia shortly after starting on citalopram for low mood. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation for answer:

  • These clinical features are suggestive of serotonin syndrome, particularly due to drug interaction between linezolid(an antibiotic with weak MAO Inhibitor activity)and citalopram(SSRI) both of which increases the serotonin levels alarmingly.
  • Serotonin syndrome (serotonin toxicity) is a potentially life-threatening condition caused by excessive serotonergic activity in the central nervous system. It can result from therapeutic drug use, drug interactions, or overdose involving serotonergic agents, including medications, illicit drugs, or supplements.
  • Symptoms typically include altered mental status, autonomic instability, and neuromuscular hyperactivity. Severity ranges from mild to fatal..
  • It typically presents with:
    • Mental status changes (e.g., agitation, confusion)
    • Autonomic hyperactivity (e.g., hyperthermia, tachycardia, diaphoresis)
    • Neuromuscular abnormalities (e.g., rigidity, clonus, hyperreflexia)
  • Diagnosis is clinical, often using the Hunter criteria, and relies on a detailed medication history. Treatment involves immediate discontinuation of the offending agents and supportive care.

Explanation of other options:

Drug Overdose(Option B):Overdose typically presents with dose-related toxicities, often in isolation (e.g., CNS depression in opioid OD, cardiac issues in TCA OD).There’s no history of excess ingestion.

Alcohol Withdrawal State(Option C):Occurs within 6–48 hours after abrupt cessation of heavy alcohol use.Symptoms: tremors, agitation, autonomic instability, seizures, hallucinations.Rigidity and clonus are not typical, and the timeline or history of alcohol use is not supportive.

Metabolic Disturbance(Option D):Conditions like hyponatremia, hypoglycemia, hepatic or uremic encephalopathy can cause confusion, but muscle rigidity and hyperreflexia are not characteristic.Also, these would not be caused immediately after adding citalopram.

questions.text: Which of the following conditions is least likely to be an indication for electroconvulsive therapy?
questions.solution:
Explanation for answer:

  • ECT is not a standard line of treatment for obsessive-compulsive disorder.
  • Electroconvulsive therapy (ECT) is a somatic treatment in which a generalized seizure is artificially induced by passing an electrical current through the brain, under controlled medical conditions, for therapeutic purposes.

questions.text: A 7-year-old boy diagnosed with attention-deficit hyperactivity disorder (ADHD) has been on methylphenidate for the past six months with good improvement in his symptoms. At a follow-up visit, his mother reports the recent development of motor tics over the past 2 weeks. Which of the following is the most appropriate alternative medication for his ADHD symptoms?
questions.solution:
Explanation for answer:

  • Atomoxetineis a non-stimulant and the most suitable alternative in patients with motor tics and ADHD.It is a non-stimulant, selective norepinephrine reuptake inhibitor (NRI).
  • It is used in patients with ADHD and comorbidities like anxiety, stimulant induced tics or tourette syndrome and in Oppositional Defiant Disorder etc.
  • It may be used as a first-line alternative to stimulants such as methylphenidateand dexamphetamine.
  • Side Effects of Atomoxetine:
    • Decreased appetite
    • GI upset (nausea, abdominal pain)
    • Sleep disturbances

Explanation of other options: 

Carbamazepine (Option B) is used for epilepsy and bipolar disorder, not ADHD, and does not address core ADHD symptoms.

Modafinil (Option C), used for narcolepsy, is not approved for ADHD and lacks evidence for managing core symptoms.

Risperidone (Option D), an antipsychotic, may reduce tics or aggression but is not effective for core ADHD symptoms like inattention and hyperactivity.
